title: How to Keep Soil Moist

steps.headline: Mix organic compost into your soil.
steps.description: Compost will also improve soil drainage and water retention, as well as improve the overall nutrient composition of the soil. Spread handfuls of the material over the surface of the soil, then use a till or a pitchfork and mix the compost with your existing soil. Organic compost is most useful in yards or garden beds, rather than potted plants. Conventional organic compost will have a pH level of around 7 and contains nutrients that will strengthen your soil. Compost is a great way to get rid of organic waste in a natural way and will add needed nutrients to your soil as well.

steps.headline: Mix perlite or vermiculite into your soil for potted plants.
steps.description: Perlite and vermiculite are non-organic types of compost that can increase water retention and absorption. Mix the material into your soil as you would with organic compost. This material is ideal for potted plants or growing a plant from a seed.

steps.headline: Till sphagnum moss and/or humus into your soil.
steps.description: Sphagnum moss and humus are loose materials that can improve water retention and help aerate your soil. Add a .5–1 inch (1.3–2.5 cm) layer over your existing soil, then use a till or pitchfork to mix the material with your soil. Over the next couple of days, the existing soil and organic material should fully mix and decrease potential water runoff when it rains.

steps.headline: Spread mulch or grass clippings around your plants.
steps.description: Mulch and grass clippings help the ground absorb moisture from rainwater and can slow down the process of evaporation. Take handfuls of the clippings or mulch and spread it evenly around plants and trees. Leave 1–3 inches (2.5–7.6 cm) of space between the plant's trunk, or leader, and the mulch. Avoid piling up mulch around the base of a plant or you’ll create an unhealthy mulch volcano.

steps.headline: Till your soil.
steps.description: Regularly tilling the soil will improve aeration and will prevent water from pooling on the top of your lawn. Dig into the ground 3–5 inches (7.6–12.7 cm) with a till, pitchfork, or shovel and turn the soil over. Go up and down the area and turn over all of the soil in the yard. Once the soil has been turned over, you can level it out with a till or rake. Even if you want to keep the soil moist, you don't want it to pool on the surface of the soil because it's bad for plants and your lawn. Soils with a high clay or sand content tend to pack down faster than balanced soils.

steps.headline: Pull weeds out of the soil.
steps.description: Weeds will soak up the moisture in the soil and will compete with the plants you want to grow. Dig around the weed with a gardening spade to loosen the soil surrounding it. Then pull the weed out of the ground, making sure to remove the entire root system. Continue to remove weeds whenever you notice them.

steps.headline: Install water absorbent mats under potted plants.
steps.description: Water absorbent mats, also called capillary mats, are made of an absorbent material like wool and will retain water. You can purchase one of these mats at a gardening store or online. Place the mat in the bottom of the pot, then place your soil and plant over the mat. When you water your plant, the mat will absorb the water and keep the soil moist.

steps.headline: Move potted plants under shade to prevent evaporation.
steps.description: If you are in a hot area and water evaporates quickly, move them under the shade of a tree or ledge to boost moisture retention. If you notice that your leaves or flowers are drying out or dying, it could mean that they are getting too much sun.

steps.headline: Water your soil in the morning.
steps.description: Watering your soil when the sun is out will cause it to evaporate quicker, which is why watering it in the morning is better. If you are trying to boost water retention, water it first thing in the morning. Watering your soil in the morning also prevents plants from catching diseases.

steps.headline: Water your soil manually 2-3 times a week.
steps.description: On average, your soil should get 1–2 inches (2.5–5.1 cm) of water each week. If your soil is drying out, water it with a garden hose or watering can. Press your finger 1–2 inches (2.5–5.1 cm) into the surface of the soil. If it feels dry under the surface, you know you need to water it more. Your soil should feel moist by the touch but shouldn’t be overly saturated. If your soil is muddy, you know you’re overwatering it. Use a gardening hose on larger lawns. Keep in mind that certain plants will need more or less watering. Research the water needs of the plants you have to make sure you're not giving them too much or too little water.

steps.headline: Use sprinklers instead of watering by hand.
steps.description: A programmed sprinkler system will enable you to water your soil on a regular schedule. This is especially useful if you aren’t around to water the soil yourself. Program your sprinkler system to provide the appropriate amount of water to your soil. If you notice the sprinklers are oversaturating the soil, reduce how long they stay on or install a water sensor that will automatically turn them off once your soil reaches a certain saturation level. Sprinklers are inefficient when it's over 90 °F (32 °C) out because the water often evaporates before it is absorbed into the soil.

steps.headline: Use a drip irrigation system for more consistent moisture.
steps.description: A drip irrigation system is made up of a system of tubes connected to a water source. This method is typically more effective than using a sprinkler system because the water is delivered directly to the soil. Hire a professional to install the system or purchase a drip irrigation kit and put it together yourself.
